form.steps:
1. Stand in front of a box with your feet slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, toes slightly pointed out. The box height should allow you to squat down until your thighs are roughly parallel to the ground. 
2. Place a barbell across your upper back, actively pulling it down onto your traps. 
3. Inhale, brace your core, and lift the barbell off the rack by straightening your legs. Take a couple of steps back to clear the rack. 
4. Keeping your back straight and core engaged, slowly lower yourself down by pushing your hips back and bending your knees. Maintain a controlled descent. 
5. Sit back onto the box, ensuring you maintain a neutral spine and don't relax your muscles. Pause briefly on the box. 
6. Drive through your heels and extend your hips and knees to return to a standing position. Exhale as you complete the movement.

form.Foot Placement: Feet slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, toes slightly pointed out.
form.Back: Keep your back straight and maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
form.Core: Engage your core to stabilize your spine and prevent injury.
form.Hips: Initiate the descent by pushing your hips back, as if you were sitting down in a chair.
form.Knees: Keep your knees in line with your toes, preventing them from caving inwards.
form.Weight Distribution: Distribute your weight evenly across your feet, focusing on pushing through your heels.
form.Head: Maintain a neutral head position, looking straight ahead.

commonMistakes.Rounding the Back: This is a common mistake that can lead to lower back pain. Ensure you maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
commonMistakes.Knee Cave-In: Allowing your knees to collapse inwards can strain your knee joints. Focus on pushing your knees outwards, in line with your toes.
commonMistakes.Not Sitting Back: Squatting straight down instead of pushing your hips back can put excessive stress on your knees. Remember to initiate the movement by pushing your hips back.
commonMistakes.Bouncing Off the Box: Avoid bouncing off the box at the bottom of the movement. This can lead to a loss of control and increase the risk of injury. Instead, control the descent and pause briefly on the box.
commonMistakes.Heels Lifting Off the Ground: This indicates that your weight is shifting forward, putting more stress on your knees. Focus on keeping your weight evenly distributed and pushing through your heels.

comments.Purpose: The box squat is a variation of the traditional squat that can be beneficial for improving strength, power, and technique. It can also be helpful for lifters with mobility restrictions.
comments.Box Height: The height of the box can be adjusted based on your individual needs and goals. A lower box will generally be more challenging, while a higher box can be used to focus on specific areas of the movement.
comments.Pause on the Box: The pause on the box can vary in duration. A shorter pause is typically used for developing power, while a longer pause can help improve positional awareness and force production from the bottom of the squat.
comments.Safety: As with any exercise, proper form and technique are crucial for preventing injuries. Start with a lighter weight and gradually increase the load as you become more comfortable with the movement.

alternativesAndVariations.Regular Squat: The traditional squat is a great alternative that works for the same muscle groups. The main difference is that it doesn't involve a pause at the bottom of the movement.
alternativesAndVariations.Front Squat: The front squat places the barbell across the front of your shoulders, emphasizing the quads more than the box squat.
alternativesAndVariations.Goblet Squat: This variation involves holding a weight (dumbbell or kettlebell) close to your chest, which can help improve core stability and squat mechanics.
alternativesAndVariations.Bulgarian Split Squat: This single-leg exercise can be a challenging alternative that targets the quads, glutes, and hamstrings.

box-squat.tempo: 31X0 (3 seconds lowering, 1 second pause at the bottom, Explosive lifting, 0 seconds pause at the top)
